newsitem.title: MEXICO: In Ireland, Mexico ex-president questioned on killing.
newsitem.headline: In Ireland, Mexico ex-president questioned on killing.

text.p: Mexican ex-president Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who lives in self-imposed exile in Ireland, was questioned on Wednesday by prosecutors investigating the 1994 killing of a top Mexican politician, the government said.

"Carlos Salinas de Gortari answered an extensive list of questions and handed over a document which will be added to the corresponding investigation," the Mexican Foreign Ministry and Attorney General's Office said in a joint statement.
Salinas, who left Mexico in disgrace in March 1995 following the arrest of his elder brother on murder charges in a separate case, gave evidence at the Mexican Embassy in Dublin, the statement said.
The special prosecutor in charge of probing the March 23, 1994 assassination of ruling party presidential candidate Luis Donaldo Colosio was in charge of the questioning of Salinas.
Colosio was the hand-picked choice of Salinas to run for president for the long-ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI).

His death catapulted his campaign manager Ernesto Zedillo into the PRI candidacy and Zedillo easily won August 1994 presidential elections. No PRI candidate has lost a presidential race since the party's formation in 1929.
Opposition politicians, many convinced that Salinas was involved in the killing, had demanded that the former president be brought back to Mexico to testify in the case.
Salinas has denied any involvement in the assassination and even went on a brief hunger strike in March last year to demand that authorities make clear he was not a suspect.
Officials have said Salinas was likely to be questioned as a witness to events surrounding the death rather than as a suspect.

Colosio was shot dead at the end of campaign rally in the northern city of Tijuana. One man is serving a 45-year sentence for the killing but prosecutors believe his death was the result of a conspiracy involving other people.
